**Interpretable Machine Learning Models for Predicting Appendicitis in Pediatric Patients**

Various machine learning models have been proposed to predict the probability of appendicitis in pediatric patients. These models can be broadly classified into globally-interpretable and locally-interpretable categories.

Globally-Interpretable Models:

*   Varying-coefficient models (Hastie & Tibshirani, 1993) allow for flexible functional relationships between features and the response variable.
*   Generalized additive models (not listed in table) can also be used to model complex relationships between features.

Locally-Interpretable Models:

*   Neural networks with attention mechanisms (Schwab et al., 2019; Koh et al., 2020) allow for feature importance and partial dependence plots, providing insights into the predictions.
*   Self-explaining neural networks (Alvarez-Melis & Jaakkola, 2018) provide a layer of abstraction to explain the decision-making process.

Other Models:

*   Symbolic regression (Udrescu & Tegmark, 2020) can be used to model complex relationships between features and the response variable.
*   DeepPINK (Lu et al., 2018) uses paired-input nonlinear knockoffs for deep feature selection.

Note that some models may not satisfy all properties listed in Table 6.
